div.p: Greetings and best wishes. Upon returning from Franconia on February 24th, the distinguished Franz Muralt handed me your letters. I read the previous ones with great pleasure. Although I have not yet fully explained myself on all matters, I strongly approve, praise, and proclaim most of them, indeed almost all, and I know them to be true. And because the matters on which I have a slightly different opinion are not of great importance, and I have previously convinced myself, and am more convinced by reading yours, I refrain from disputing them either with you or with others.

For I prefer to appear as if I have seen nothing in matters that are not so necessary, rather than to attack the opinions of others that stem from a pious and sincere heart. Therefore, on to other matters.

First, I do not ask you to explain in detail what you think of our Antiparacelsian disputations. For I know how busy you are. However, I would like others to read them and inform me about those things which are either not correct, obscure, false, out of place, or too concise, so that I may have the opportunity to correct them in the future.

Then I learned from Franz Muralt that he, along with his brother and father, treats not only those diseases to which other surgeons usually apply their hands, but also internal ones: among these, dropsy and the plague, and they have produced great and illustrious experiments in these. I wish to know if this is indeed the case. For many boast of things they have never accomplished, or not in the way they claim to have accomplished them.

We have nothing new that I think you would want to be informed about. I will only say that Mr. Evichius recently wrote to me and made such an honorable mention of you that I think nothing in his life has been more pleasant than your friendship.
He eagerly awaits your letters, and values them like a treasure. May God Almighty bless you. Amen. The price of grain has somewhat decreased.
I bought a bushel of grain for one and a half florins and more, which is less than before.
Franz says that he or his brother treated your son for a rupture in a vein. I ask you to inform me how much I should believe this.
Your most observant, Thomas Erastus, to the most learned theologian and most faithful pastor of the RÃ¶tteln church, his distinguished relative, Johann Jakob Grynaeus.
